text:
Introduction
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and may peace and blessings be upon our Prophet Muhammad, his family, and all his companions. To proceed:
Many Muslims suffer from frequent doubts and whispers regarding the existence of God Almighty, alongside the abundance of those who cast doubt on God's existence and their spread in various media outlets, especially on the World Wide Web and social media platforms. This necessitates clarifying the ruling on doubt and whispers regarding the existence of God Almighty, as this pertains to God Almighty, and the honor of knowledge is derived from the honor of the known subject, especially this knowledge related to the greatest principle of faith, which is belief in God Almighty.
Researching the issue of the existence of God Almighty is the most important and loftiest of researches, for belief in His existence, Glory be to Him, relative to the rest of the principles and branches, is like the root of a tree relative to the trunk and branches. It is the root of roots and the foundation of religion. The greater a person's share of belief in God, the greater his share in Islam. Casting doubt on the existence of God Almighty for a Muslim makes the disbelief of people greater, to the point that a specialist in doctrine said: 'It would have been appropriate for us not to dwell much on the proofs of God's existence, because human nature (Fitrah) testifies to that, and hardly any denier of the Creator's existence was known in the past except for a very few, who do not represent a significant percentage of humanity. However, the deviation today has reached the lowest depths, so we now see people claiming there is no Creator, making this statement a doctrine upon which they build their lives. States numbering hundreds of millions of people have been established on this doctrine. This statement has spread everywhere, books have been written on it, it has developed a philosophy taught [in schools], and its proponents have tried to call it the scientific method and provide evidence for it.' (1)
With the spread of whispers (Waswasah) among many people, there was a great necessity to clarify the ruling on whispers regarding the existence of God Almighty, to know the extent of its impact on the Muslim's belief, what rulings result from those whispers, and how a Muslim deals with them.

Definition of Scientific Terms:
1 - First: Definition of 'Athar' (Effect/Trace) Linguistically and Terminologically:
A - 'Athar' Linguistically: It is used to mean several things. Ibn Faris (d. 395 AH) said: (Athar) has three roots: presenting something, mentioning something, and the trace of the thing remaining. (1) Ibn Manzur (d. 711 AH) said: Al-Athar with a movement (on the Tha) - what remains of the trace of a thing. Al-Ta'athur is retaining the trace in the thing, and 'Athara fi al-shay' means he left a trace in it. (2)
B - 'Athar' Terminologically: The usage of the word (Athar) does not depart from the linguistic meanings. It is used to indicate three meanings: The first meaning is the result, which is what is obtained from the thing. The second is the sign. The third meaning is the part, or what results from the thing. (3) Therefore, the predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them, see that 'Athar' is intended to mean knowledge, or the essence of knowledge, or knowledge that is extracted, or the result of a thing. Ibn Jarir, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the interpretation of the Almighty's saying: {or a trace of knowledge, if you should be truthful} [Al-Ahqaf: 4], meaning: 'The remainder of knowledge, because that is what is known in the speech of the Arabs.' (4)

Second: Definition of Doubt (Shakk) Linguistically and Terminologically
Doubt Linguistically: Doubt is used to mean several things, most importantly:
1 - Interpenetration/Piercing, as in: I pierced him (shakaktuhu) with the spear, meaning I stabbed him with it; so its head entered his body. (1)
2 - Doubt meaning lack of certainty; so his saying: I doubted (shakaktu) the matter or became doubtful (tashakaktu) about it means my certainty went away, because for the doubter, it is as if the two matters were pierced (shukka) into a single pierce (mishk); and he is not certain of either of them. That is why it is said: You pierced (shakakta) between two leaves, if you stuck the stick into them and they joined together. (2)
3 - Hesitation: Meaning hesitation between two things; without preferring one over the other. (3)
And from it is the Almighty's saying: {So if you are in doubt, [O Muhammad], about that which We have revealed to you, then ask those who have been reading the Scripture before you. The truth has certainly come to you from your Lord, so never be among the doubters.} [Yunus: 94].

Doubt Terminologically
The definition of doubt in terminology is not far from the linguistic definition. Doubt is defined as: "That which contradicts certainty, and its holder wavers between two things" (1). This is indicated by one of the interpretations of the Almighty's saying: {Their messengers said, "Can there be doubt about Allah, Creator of the heavens and earth? He invites you that He may forgive you of your sins, and He delays your death for a specified term."} [Ibrahim: 10]. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Is there doubt about His existence? For the natural dispositions (Fitrah) testify to His existence and are naturally inclined to acknowledge Him. Acknowledgment of Him is necessary in sound natural dispositions. However, doubt and confusion may occur to some of them, so they need to look into the evidence leading to His existence; that is why the messengers said to them, guiding them to the way of knowing Him, that He is the (Creator of the heavens and earth) who created and originated them without a preceding example. The evidences of occurrence, creation, and subjugation are apparent upon them, so they must have a Maker, who is Allah, there is no god but He, the Creator of everything, its God and its Owner." (2)
So doubt in the existence of God Almighty is hesitation regarding His existence, Glory be to Him; and lack of certainty in His existence, Glory be to Him and Exalted is He. (3)

Third: Definition of Whisper (Waswas) Linguistically and Terminologically
Waswas Linguistically
Waswas: "The devil, the whisper of the hunter and dogs, the sound of jewelry. And Waswasah: the speech of the soul and the devil with what has no benefit." (1)
Waswas Terminologically
Waswas and Waswasah are: What is cast into the heart and is hidden from creation so they do not view it, either as self-talk or by the act of the devil. It is a mere passing thought that did not settle in the heart, let alone the heart knotting upon it; rather, it hates it. (2)
It was said that Waswasah is: "Thoughts that are not stable, nor brought about by a doubt that occurred, and have no basis." (3)
The Difference Between Doubt and Whisper
Given the confusion among many Muslims between doubt and whisper, the difference between them must be clarified. The difference between them has an impact on the ruling of each, as will become clear in the coming sections, God willing. The predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them, see that doubt contradicts certainty; doubt and certainty do not gather. As for whisper, it is merely thoughts and ideas, either what the soul whispers or what the devil whispers, while certainty remains in the heart regarding the existence of God Almighty, (4) evidenced by the saying of God Almighty: {Indeed, there is for him no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord} [An-Nahl: 99]. So he has no power over the believers due to the tranquility of their hearts with faith.

Fourth: Definition of Doctrine (Aqidah) Linguistically and Terminologically
A - Aqidah Linguistically: Derived from 'Al-Aqd' (tying/knotting). One tied (Aqada) the rope means he tightened it (1). 'Al-Aqd' is tying firmly, and from it comes tightening, ratification, cohesion, compacting, affirming, and securing. (2) It is applied to what is in the heart, so it is said: He believed (I'taqada) such and such with his heart (3). Allah the Blessed and Almighty said: {Allah will not impose blame upon you for what is meaningless in your oaths, but He will impose blame upon you for [breaking] what you intended of oaths} [Al-Ma'idah: 89]. "It is: The judgment in which there is no doubt for the one who believes it. So Aqidah in religion is what is intended as belief without action, like the belief in the existence of God and the sending of messengers. The plural is 'Aqa'id'. In summary, whatever a person knots his heart upon with certainty is an Aqidah, whether it is true or false" (4).
B - Aqidah Terminologically: Aqidah in general terminology is: "Matters which the heart must believe in, and the soul must find tranquility in, until they become a steadfast certainty not mixed with doubt nor mingled with suspicion. Meaning: Firm faith that is not infiltrated by doubt for the believer. It must be consistent with reality, accepting neither doubt nor conjecture. If knowledge does not reach the level of firm certainty, it is not called Aqidah." (5)
Islamic Aqidah: Is "Firm belief in Allah and what is due to Him in His Divinity, Lordship, Names, and Attributes; belief in His Angels, Books, Messengers, the Last Day, and Destiny, its good and its evil; and in everything that authentic texts brought regarding the principles of religion, matters of the unseen and its news, and what the predecessors (Salaf) agreed upon; and submission to Allah Almighty in judgment, command, destiny, and legislation, and to His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, with obedience, arbitration, and following." (6)
Aqidah, in terms of being a science according to the concept of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, includes the following topics: Tawhid - Tawhid of Divinity (Uluhiyyah), Tawhid of Lordship (Rububiyyah), and Tawhid of Names and Attributes - Faith (Iman), Islam, Unseen matters (Ghaybiyyat), Prophethoods, Destiny, Reports, Principles of definitive rulings, and all principles of religion and belief. Following this is the refutation of the people of desires and innovations and all deviant sects and creeds, and the stance towards them (7).

Topic One: The Reality of the Existence of God Almighty
The reality of the existence of God Almighty is an established truth according to the righteous predecessors (Salaf al-Salih), may Allah have mercy on them. The default for them is certainty in the existence of God Almighty, unlike the deviant sects from the people of Kalam (speculative theology) and those who agreed with them in the past and in our present time. For the default for them is doubt, not certainty, contrary to the righteous predecessors, Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah. "Deviation in affirming the existence of God Almighty was found among the Jahmiyyah and innovators, as a result of being influenced by the Zanadiqah (heretics) and the Indian Sumaniyyah. The deviation of the Mutakallimin (theologians) from the Mu'tazila (1) and others expanded, so they stipulated speculative reasoning (Nazar) and inference (Istidlal), and doubt for the attainment of knowledge of the Maker, according to their claim. text:
First: The Evidence of Fitrah (Innate Nature)
People of sound nature are all agreed on acknowledging God Almighty. (1) "For acknowledgment of the Creator, Glory be to Him, and His perfection, is an innate, necessary matter for one whose nature is sound" (2). "Sound nature testifies to the existence of God without proof. The Quran did not prolong the argumentation for the existence of God Almighty, because the Quran establishes that sound natures, and souls that have not been polluted by the filth of polytheism, are naturally disposed to acknowledge His existence, Glory be to Him. Indeed, His unification - Glory be to Him - is an innate, axiomatic matter; Allah Almighty said: {So direct your face toward the religion, inclining to truth. [Adhere to] the fitrah of Allah upon which He has created [all] people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know.} [Ar-Rum: 30]. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, stated the innate nature of acknowledging the Creator. In the two Sahihs from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (No child is born but upon Fitrah. He is made a Jew, a Christian, or a Magian by his parents. As a beast produces a whole beast; do you perceive any defect in it?) Then Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, says: Read if you wish (The fitrah of Allah upon which He has created [all] people) (3). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not say in the Hadith 'and they make him a Muslim', because Islam is in agreement with Fitrah." (4)
Therefore, the Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, did not engage much in proving the existence of God Almighty, nor did they amass evidences to establish it, because it is one of the accepted issues settled in human nature." (5)

text:
Second: The Indication of Sharia (Revelation)
When looking at the legal evidences from the infallible revelation, we find that they indicate the existence of God Almighty through affirming His attributes, Glory be to Him, which indicate His life, self-subsistence, highness, knowledge, and other attributes pointing to His existence, Glory be to Him. Whether that is in the Book of God Almighty or in the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him. In the Book of God Almighty, He says, High and Exalted: {Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep... the verse} [Al-Baqarah: 255]. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "{THE EVER-LIVING, THE SUSTAINER} meaning the Living in Himself who never dies, the Sustainer of others." (1)
And the Noble Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, says, clarifying that God Almighty exists, and that He is the Creator of all creatures, including the heavens and the earth: (Allah was, and there was nothing before Him, and His Throne was on the water, then He created the heavens and the earth, and He wrote everything in the Reminder (Preserved Tablet)). (2) And in a narration: (Allah was, and there was nothing other than Him, and His Throne was on the water, and He wrote everything in the Reminder, and He created the heavens and the earth). (3)
Therefore, the Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, see that faith in God Almighty is only through faith in His existence, Lordship, Names, and Attributes, Glory be to Him. And that a servant is not a believer until he believes in the six pillars of faith; which are: Belief in Allah, His Angels, His Books, His Messengers, belief in the Last Day, and in Destiny, its good and its evil" (4), "and that faith in God Almighty is believing in what He said, commanded, obligated, and forbade; from everything the Messengers brought and the Books revealed" (5).

text:
Third: The Indication of Reason for the Existence of God Almighty
Sound reason indicates the existence of God Almighty, and agrees with the texts of the Sharia in that. This is clearly evident in the following:
1 - The Argument of Creation and Origination:
Indeed, these creatures, the preceding and the succeeding ones, must have a Creator who originated them; for they cannot originate themselves by themselves, nor can they come into existence by chance. They cannot originate themselves by themselves because a thing does not create itself; because before its existence it was nothingness; so how can it be a creator?! And they cannot come into existence by chance; because every occurrence must have an originator, and because their existence on this marvelous, precise system, harmonious coordination, and cohesive link between causes and their effects, and between beings with one another, categorically prevents their existence from being by chance. If these creatures could not originate themselves by themselves, nor exist by chance, it is determined that they have an Originator; and He is Allah, Lord of the Worlds. Allah Almighty mentioned this rational evidence and definitive proof in Surah At-Tur; where He Almighty said: {Or were they created by nothing, or were they the creators [of themselves]?} [At-Tur: 35]; meaning they were not created without a creator, nor are they the ones who created themselves; so it is determined that their Creator is Allah, Blessed and Exalted. That is why when Jubayr bin Mut'im, may Allah be pleased with him, heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reciting Surah At-Tur and reached these

verses: {Or were they created by nothing, or were they the creators [of themselves]? * Or did they create the heavens and the earth? Rather, they are not certain. * Or have they the depositories [containing the provision] of your Lord? Or are they the controllers [of them]?} [At-Tur: 35-37], and Jubayr was a polytheist at that time, he said: (My heart almost flew, and that was the first time faith settled in my heart) (1). (2)
So God Almighty created the creatures, most importantly man, whom God Almighty originated from nothingness. God Almighty says clarifying that: {Does man not remember that We created him before, while he was nothing?} [Maryam: 67]. "Using the creation of man as evidence for the Creator is of the utmost goodness and uprightness. It is a correct rational method, and it is legitimate (Shar'i); the Quran indicated it, guided people to it, clarified it, and directed towards it." (3)
Therefore, the Holy Quran indicated the creation of creation and that God Almighty is their Creator in many verses; among them His Almighty's saying: {Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and earth in six days and then established Himself above the Throne. He covers the night with the day, [another night] chasing it rapidly; and [He created] the sun, the moon, and the stars, subjected by His command. Unquestionably, His is the creation and the command; blessed is Allah, Lord of the worlds.} [Al-A'raf: 54]. And His Almighty's saying: {Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and the earth in six days and then established Himself above the Throne, arranging the matter. There is no intercessor except after His permission. That is Allah, your Lord, so worship Him. Then will you not remember?} [Yunus: 3]. And He, Glory be to Him, says clarifying that He is the Creator and whatever else is created, and since He is the Creator, Glory be to Him, of everything, then He exists, Glory be to Him: {Allah is the Creator of all things, and He is, over all things, Disposer of affairs. To Him belong the keys of the heavens and the earth. And they who disbelieve in the verses of Allah - it is those who are the losers.} [Az-Zumar: 62-63].

text:
2 - The Argument of Care and Perfection:
God's care for His servants by sending messengers is proof of His existence, Glory be to Him. For what the messengers brought of God's laws, comprising all that benefits creation, indicates that the One who sent them with it is a Merciful, Wise Lord, especially this Glorious Quran which incapacitated humans and jinn from bringing the like of it. (1) God Almighty says clarifying His sending of messengers to His servants: {Indeed, We have sent you with the truth as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. And there was no nation but that there had passed within it a warner.} [Fatir: 24]. Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And no nation has passed from the sons of Adam except that God sent warners to them, and removed excuses from them." (2)
There is no doubt that looking at and pondering over the heavens and the earth and the creatures between them, and the miraculous action, precise management, care, and perfection therein; clearly indicates the existence of the Creating, Wise Lord; who perfected everything He created. God Almighty says clarifying this perfection: {It is not allowable for the sun to reach the moon, nor does the night overtake the day, but each, in an orbit, is swimming.} [Ya-Sin: 40]. Many verses have been reported pointing to this meaning; among them His Almighty's saying: {Have We not made the earth a resting place? And the mountains as stakes? And We created you in pairs.} [An-Naba: 6-8], and His Almighty's saying: {Blessed is He who has placed in the sky great stars and placed therein a [burning] lamp and luminous moon.} [Al-Furqan: 61] and His Almighty's saying: {Then do they not look at the camels - how they are created? And at the sky - how it is raised? And at the mountains - how they are erected? And at the earth - how it is spread out?} [Al-Ghashiyah: 17-20]. "These verses indicate the encouragement to reflect on God's creatures which indicate His Tawhid (Unity), Glory be to Him. If His Unity is established, acknowledgment of His existence, Glory be to Him, follows inevitably." (3)

text:
Fourth: The Indication of Sense (Hiss) for the Existence of God Almighty
Sense indicates the existence of God, for a human calls upon God Almighty, saying: O Lord! And asks for something, then it is answered for him. This is a sensory indication. He himself called upon no one but God, and God answered him; he saw that with his own eyes. Similarly, we hear about those who preceded and those in our era, that God answered them. The Bedouin who entered while the Messenger, peace be upon him, was addressing the people on Friday said: Livestock are dying and the roads are cut off; so pray to God to give us rain. Anas said: By God, there was not a cloud or a trace of cloud in the sky, and between us and Sala' (a mountain in Medina from whose direction clouds come) there was no house or building. immediately after the supplication of the Messenger, peace be upon him, a cloud like a shield appeared, rose in the sky, spread, thundered, flashed, and rain fell. The Messenger, peace be upon him, did not descend [from the pulpit] except that rain was dripping from his beard, peace and blessings be upon him. (1) This is a real event indicating the existence of the Creator with sensory evidence. In the Quran, there are many evidences for that, among them His Almighty's saying: {And [mention] Job, when he called to his Lord, "Indeed, adversity has touched me, and you are the Most Merciful of the merciful." * So We responded to him...} the verse [Al-Anbiya: 83-84]. (2)
Among the sensory evidences for the existence of God Almighty is witnessing the miracles of the Prophets, for they indicate that their Sender exists, Glory be to Him and Exalted is He. In the Holy Quran, there is what supports the indication of miracles for proving the existence of the Creator, Glory be to Him, in the dialogue that took place between Moses, peace be upon him, and Pharaoh, the denier of the Lord of the Worlds, where God Almighty said: {Pharaoh said, "And what is the Lord of the worlds?" [Moses] said, "The Lord of the heavens and earth and that between them, if you should be convinced." [Pharaoh] said to those around him, "Do you not hear?" [Moses] said, "Your Lord and the Lord of your first forefathers." [Pharaoh] said, "Indeed, your 'messenger' who has been sent to you is mad." [Moses] said, "Lord of the east and the west and that between them, if you were to reason." [Pharaoh] said, "If you take a god other than me, I will surely place you among those imprisoned." [Moses] said, "Even if I brought you something manifest?" [Pharaoh] said, "Then bring it,

The signs are the hand and the staff, and there are other signs which are: shortage of crops, years of drought, the flood, locusts, lice, frogs, and blood. They are nine clear signs (1). As for the miracles of Jesus, peace be upon him, they were numerous, clarified by God's saying: {And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say], 'Indeed I have come to you with a sign from your Lord in that I design for you from clay [that which is] like the form of a bird, then I breathe into it and it becomes a bird by permission of Allah. This is because it is a miracle remaining through time, speaking of his prophethood, peace and blessings be upon him, in every time and place, while all other miracles with which God supported all His other prophets have ended and gone and became history mentioned. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "As for those who followed the path of wisdom, they also have paths; such as saying: Indeed God Almighty, if He sends a messenger, commands people to believe and obey him, so He must set up for them evidence indicating his truthfulness. Topic Two: The Impact of Doubt in the Existence of God Almighty on the Muslim's Belief
Belief in God Almighty is one of the pillars of faith, and belief in God includes belief in His existence, Glory be to Him; which is one of the matters of the unseen that must be believed in. Whoever denies anything of the unseen matters is outside of Islam. For among the pillars of faith is: Belief in God Almighty by knowing Him and being certain of His existence and believing in His Lordship, Names, and Attributes (1). The Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, see that faith is speech by the tongue, belief by the heart, and action by the limbs. They say: It is speech, action, and knowledge, meaning: belief and intention (2). Doubt in the existence of God Almighty is contrary to sound natural dispositions as previously mentioned; but given its alarming spread in recent years in Islamic countries (3), it was necessary to clarify its impact on the Muslim's belief. For doubt in the existence of God Almighty is in reality doubt in His Lordship, Glory be to Him. Whoever doubts that there is no Lord, Creator, Owner, and Controller in this universe has fallen into disbelief (Kufr). And whoever denies the Lordship of God Almighty will deny His Divinity (Uluhiyyah) a fortiori; since a human cannot worship something non-existent. Given that doubt in God's Lordship leads to disbelief; because it relates to the belief that a Muslim must hold (4); I will clarify in this section the ruling on doubt in the existence of God Almighty, and what results from doubt in His existence, Glory be to Him, as follows:

text:
First: Ruling on Doubt in the Existence of God Almighty
To clarify the ruling on doubt in the existence of God Almighty, it is necessary to state the belief of the Salaf regarding the ruling of one who doubts the existence of God Almighty, and to clarify the refutation of those who used the doubt of prophets as proof, and that doubt in the existence of God Almighty leads to disbelief, as follows:
1 - The Belief of the Salaf Regarding the Ruling of One Who Doubts the Existence of God Almighty
The Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, believe that God Almighty exists; and that He is the Lord of servants, their Creator, and their Originator from nothingness, and that He is the Creator of everything (1), and that God Almighty is established above His Throne, separate from His creation, encompasses everything in knowledge, there is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing (2). That is why the Salaf, may Allah have mercy on them, say: "Affirming God Almighty is affirming existence, not affirming modality (Kayfiyyah)" (3). The Salaf believe that faith in God Almighty is one of the six pillars of faith due to the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him, in the famous Hadith of Gabriel: (Faith is to believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Last Day, and to believe in Destiny, its good and its evil) (4). Based on that, the first pillar of faith is belief in God Almighty, and belief in God Almighty includes belief in the following (5):

A - Belief in His existence, meaning: that He exists, Glory be to Him and Exalted is He.
B - Belief in His Lordship, meaning: that He, Glory be to Him, is the Lord, with no partner and no helper.
C - Belief in His Divinity, meaning: that He is the True God with no partner.
D - Belief in His Names and Attributes, meaning: affirming what God Almighty affirmed in His Book, or what His Messenger, peace be upon him, affirmed in his Sunnah of names and attributes in a manner befitting Him; without distortion (Tahrif), negation (Ta'til), asking how (Takyif), or likening (Tamthil).
As for doubt in the existence of God Almighty, the Salaf consider it disbelief in God Almighty, which they call 'Kufr al-Shakk' (Disbelief of Doubt), (1) which is hesitation, and lack of certainty in the truthfulness of the messengers. It is also called 'Kufr al-Zann' (Disbelief of Conjecture), and it is the opposite of resoluteness (Jazm)
foot_note: 1. Scholars divided disbelief into several categories under which many forms and types of polytheism fall, which are: 1) Disbelief of Denial (Juhud) and Rejection (Takdhib): This disbelief is sometimes rejection by the heart - and sometimes rejection by the tongue or limbs by concealing the truth and not submitting to it outwardly while knowing it and recognizing it inwardly, like the disbelief of the Jews in Muhammad, peace be upon him. God Almighty said about them: (And when there came to them that which they recognized, they disbelieved in it) [Al-Baqarah: 89] And He, Glory be to Him, also said: (And indeed, a party of them conceal the truth while they know [it]) (Al-Baqarah: 146). That is because rejection is not realized except from one who knew the truth and rejected it. That is why God negated that the disbelievers' rejection of the Messenger, peace be upon him, was in reality and inwardly, but rather by the tongue only; He said: (For they do not deny you, but the wrongdoers deny the verses of Allah) Al-An'am/33. And He said about Pharaoh and his people: (And they rejected them, while their inner selves were convinced thereof, out of injustice and haughtiness) [An-Naml/14]. Attached to this disbelief is the disbelief of permissible-making (Istihlal), so whoever deems lawful what he knows from the Sharia is forbidden has rejected the Messenger, peace be upon him, in what he brought, and likewise whoever forbids what he knows from the Sharia is lawful. [(A'lam al-Sunnah al-Manshurah 177) and (Nawaqid al-Iman al-Qawliyyah wa al-Amaliyyah, Abdul Aziz Al-Abdul Latif (36 – 46), Dawabit al-Takfir, Abdullah Al-Qarni (183 – 196)] 2) Disbelief of Turning Away (I'rad) and Arrogance (Istikbar): Like the disbelief of Iblis, for God Almighty says about him: (Except for Iblis. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers) [Al-Baqarah/34]. And as He said: (They say, "We have believed in Allah and in the Messenger, and we obey"; then a party of them turns away after that. And those are not believers) An-Nur/47. So He negated faith from those who turned away from action, even if they brought the speech. So it became clear that the disbelief of turning away is: abandoning the truth, not learning it and not acting upon it, whether by speech, action, or belief. The Almighty says: (But those who disbelieve turn away from what they were warned of) [Al-Ahqaf/3]. So whoever turns away from what the Messenger, peace be upon him, brought by speech, like one who says I do not follow him, or by action, like one who turns away and flees from hearing the truth he brought or puts his fingers in his ears so as not to hear, or hears it but turns away with his heart from believing in it, and with his limbs from acting, has disbelieved with the disbelief of turning away. 3) Disbelief of Hypocrisy (Nifaq): It is what is without the belief of the heart and its action, with outward submission to show off to people, like the disbelief of Ibn Salul and other hypocrites about whom God Almighty said: (And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers. They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive not except themselves and perceive [it] not... etc. verses) Al-Baqarah/8–20. 4) Disbelief of Doubt (Shakk) and Suspicion (Raybah): It is hesitation in following the truth or hesitation in it being the truth, because what is required is certainty that what the Messenger brought is truth with no doubt in it. So whoever allows for the possibility that what he brought is not truth has disbelieved; the disbelief of doubt or conjecture, as He said: (And he entered his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said, "I do not think that this will perish - ever. And I do not think the Hour will occur. And even if I should be brought back to my Lord, I will surely find better than this as a return." His companion said to him while he was conversing with him, "Have you disbelieved in He who created you from dust and then from a sperm-drop and then proportioned you [as] a man? But as for me, He is Allah, my Lord, and I do not associate with my Lord anyone.") [Al-Kahf: 35 - 38].

Section Three: The Effect of Whisperings on the Belief in Allah Almighty on the Muslim’s Creed

A Muslim may be subjected to whisperings regarding the existence of Allah Almighty, which can cause difficulty and distress. These whisperings pertain to Allah, and the following clarifies their nature and ruling:

1 - Whisperings about the Existence of Allah Almighty: There is a clear distinction between doubt and whispering. Doubt, as previously explained, is lack of certainty and cannot coexist with certainty. Whispering, however, is an intrusive matter despite certainty in the heart. Doubt occurs by human choice, whereas whisperings occur without choice. Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: 'There is a difference between doubt and whispering. Whispering is something that attacks the heart without the person’s choice. If the servant dislikes it and rejects it, this rejection is an explicit sign of faith.' 

The Salaf believed that Allah created the devils; they whisper to humans intending to mislead and ensnare them, as Allah Almighty says: {Indeed, the devils inspire their allies to dispute with you, and if you obey them, indeed, you would be associators.} [Al-An'am: 121]. Allah allows them to target whom He wills and protects from their plots whom He wills. Allah also says: {And provoke whom you can with your voice, and drive them against them with your horses and your feet, and share with them in wealth and children, but Satan only promises them deceit. Indeed, My servants…}

text: Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, when he found pages of the Torah in his hands, and he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Are you confused (1) about it, O Ibn al-Khattab? By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, I have brought it to you white and pure. Do not ask them about anything lest they tell you the truth and you belie it, or falsehood and you believe it. By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, if Moses, peace be upon him, were alive, he would have no choice but to follow me) (2). As for the treatment of doubt regarding the existence of Allah Almighty when it exists in a Muslim, it is through repentance to Allah Almighty, believing in Him, having complete certainty of His existence, and acknowledging that He is the Creator, the Provider, the Disposer of this universe. This is Tawhid al-Rububiyyah (Oneness of Lordship). The accountable person must not limit himself to this type of Tawhid; rather, Tawhid al-Uluhiyyah (Oneness of Worship) is also necessary, which is singling out Allah Almighty with worship. Sheikh Abd al-Rahman al-Sa'di, may Allah have mercy on him, says in his interpretation of the verse: {And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our Servant} [Al-Baqarah: 23]: "Proof that the one for whom guidance from error is hoped is the confused doubter who has not known truth from error. This person, if the truth is clarified to him, is likely to follow it if he is sincere in seeking the truth. As for the stubborn one who knows the truth and leaves it, his return is not possible because he left the truth after it became clear to him... Likewise, the doubter who is not sincere in seeking the truth but is turning away, not striving in his search; this one is mostly not granted success." (3) Therefore, we find the Salaf view Doubt (Shakk) and Suspicion (Rayb) in creeds as having the same meaning. Some distinguish between them and see that Shakk is more specific than Rayb (4). text: Scholars mentioned four conditions for repentance for any sin a Muslim commits, which are as follows (1): 1 - The repentance must be sincerely for Allah Almighty. 2 - He must desist from the sin. 3 - He must regret what has passed. 4 - He must resolve not to return to it in the future. 5 - If the matter relates to the rights of humans, whether their wealth, honor, or bodies, he must ask for forgiveness from the one who has a right over him, or restore the rights to their owners. Ibn al-Qayyim said: (Injustice before Allah Almighty on the Day of Resurrection has three registers (Dawawin): A register that Allah does not forgive anything from, which is Shirk (associating partners) with Him, for Allah does not forgive that partners be associated with Him. A register that Allah Almighty leaves nothing from, which is the injustice of servants to one another, for Allah Almighty exacts it all. And a register that Allah does not care about at all, which is the servant's injustice to himself between him and his Lord Almighty; this register is the lightest of registers and the fastest to be erased, for it is erased by repentance, seeking forgiveness, good deeds that wipe out sins, expiating calamities, and the like. Unlike the register of Shirk, which is not erased except by Tawhid (Monotheism), and the register of injustices [to others], which is not erased except by exiting from them to their owners and seeking their absolution) (2). The lightest of registers is erased by repentance and seeking forgiveness, and Allah Almighty forgives all sins without exception if the servant repents and returns.

text: The Fifth Topic: Treating Whispers Regarding the Existence of Allah Almighty. Whispers present themselves to the Muslim at all times, especially in his creed. His soul whispers to him, or Satan whispers to him. Satan continues to whisper to man and tries to misguide him, as Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, do not follow the footsteps of Satan. And whoever follows the footsteps of Satan - indeed, he enjoins immorality and wrongdoing. And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, not one of you would have been pure, ever, but Allah purifies whom He wills, and Allah is Hearing and Knowing} [Al-Nur: 21]. This indicates that Satan continues to try with the Muslim until he reaches the point of attempting to make him doubt the existence of Allah Almighty, in addition to the whispering of the soul that enjoins evil. This causes the Muslim distress and anxiety, especially in this grave matter, which calls for seeking a treatment for these whispers from which hardly anyone is safe. text: Results and Recommendations. Many results were reached in this study, and they can be clarified as follows: 1 - That Allah Almighty exists, He is the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence, and He, Glory be to Him, is the Creator of creation and their Originator from non-existence. This truth is indicated by sound natural disposition (Fitrah), the purified Law (Sharia), sound Reason, as well as Sense perception through witnessing great creations, miracles of Prophets, and answering the prayers of supplicants. 2 - That doubt regarding the existence of Allah Almighty is disbelief (Kufr) that expels one from Islam. The legal evidences from the Book of Allah Almighty and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, indicate that the Kufr of doubt applies to everyone who doubts the existence of Allah Almighty. Denying His existence, Exalted be He, is a denial of His Lordship, so whoever doubts that is a denier of the Messengers of Allah, peace be upon them. 3 - That if a Muslim doubts the existence of Allah Almighty, he has apostatized from the religion of Allah, and the rulings of apostasy apply to him; he is asked to repent, so if he repents [it is accepted], otherwise he is executed as an apostate. He exits Islam, his deeds are nullified, his marriage is annulled and he is separated from his wife, he is prevented from disposing of his wealth during the period of his call to repentance, and if he dies, he is not inherited from, nor washed, nor shrouded, nor prayed over, nor buried in Muslim cemeteries. 4 - That whispers regarding the existence of Allah Almighty come from the soul that enjoins evil, and from Satan who tries to misguide the Muslim and push him to doubt the existence of Allah Almighty. Therefore, seeking refuge from Satan and his whispers is prescribed. 5 - There is no effect of whispers on the Muslim's creed according to the Salaf, if the Muslim repels them and does not indulge in them. If he does that, it does not harm him, and that is explicit faith.
